| Masterlist in Bio |

P A R T  T H R E E :

Christmas was coming soon and you and Peter still hadn’t talked things out. He was back at the apartment now, and while things weren’t any worse than they were before, they certainly weren’t any better. You tiptoed around one another, and even when you were laying in bed together, holding each other close, you could feel the barrier between you.

Time seemed to be warping lately, making the days drag by yet surprise you when you see just how many of those days had passed. It had only been a couple of weeks since everything had happened, yet it felt like it should have been a couple of months. But now Christmas was right around the corner and you didn’t have any gift shopping done. The Christmas tree wasn’t up, no Christmas cookies were baked, the decorations were still in the office you and Peter had dubbed a storage room, and still you had no motivation to do any of it. Not without Peter. Peter was what made Christmas…well, Christmas. You had to do it, though. Maybe you could text Peter a few names to pick up gifts for—Tony, Bruce, Rhodey, and… Steve, perhaps.

No, not Steve. Tony? Sure. Rhodey? Why not? And Bruce? Even better. But not Steve. You were just as close to him as Peter was, and because of that you always picked out his gift together. But unless something drastically changed within a week, one of you was going to have to do it on your own.

You knew it wasn’t going to.

Your stomach turned violently, causing you to rush to the toilet. You’d been feeling sicker than usual the past few days now, but you’d never actually thrown up until now. Thank goodness Peter was already at work, or he would be worried as all get out. Not to mention it’d make talking honestly and openly impossible if Peter thought for even one second that it was him who’d caused you to be physically ill. But he would only be half right, because you were as much a part of this as he was; you were both equally responsible.

With a still-turning stomach and a heavy heart, you stood and continued your morning routine, leaving for work ten minutes later. Work equaled distraction, and distraction equaled a blank mind—just like every other day.

—

The pan sizzled as the vegetables fried inside it, and the smell surprisingly didn’t send your stomach into another frenzy. Stir fry was safe. You made a mental note of that.

The door to the apartment opened, and your heart beat quicker at Peter’s presence; that used to be a good thing, but now your racing pulse was for entirely different reasons. Reasons you still weren’t brave enough to bring up.

“It smells good,” Peter offered with a weak smile when he came into the kitchen, his voice unsure.

“Thank you,” you said just as unsurely, but more stiff.

Silence fell over the room, and just a few weeks ago you’d have found it alarming (you and Peter always kept the conversation going unless something was seriously wrong), but now it was normal. It was just like every other day.

Seriously wrong had turned into normal. Funny how that worked.

While you were finishing up with the stir fry, Peter pulled two plates and cups from the cupboard, setting the table without a word. Your stomach twisted again at the reminder that this wasn’t how it used to be, but you managed to calm it with a quick internal scolding. It didn’t mean, however, that you weren’t still dying for Peter to sneak his arms around you from behind and rest his chin on your shoulder as you dished up your plates, or that you didn’t still want to sweep all this under the rug so you could kiss him again without feeling guilty.

“…Y/N? Y/N, you there?”

You startled, only now realizing you’d been standing in the same position for who knows how long. “Yeah, yeah, I….sorry,” you replied, shaking your head as you walked the pan to the table.

Peter was staring—you could feel his eyes burning into the back of your head—and when you turned to meet his gaze you saw the unspoken question of: Are you okay? But he never voiced it, probably knowing the answer already. He instead swallowed and cleared his throat, shoving his hands in his pockets and slightly dipping his head as he asked, “What‘s on your mind?”

The question was dangerous, but you were sure he knew that. Peter was too intelligent not to—which also happened to be the reason you couldn’t lie to him. The boy would pick up on it in an instant. But you didn’t have to tell the whole truth either.

“We need to get Steve a present,” you said quietly, watching as your husband’s eyes lit up for a moment at the mentioning of the superhero’s name then dimming again when you finished your sentence. It made your heart hurt to see Peter look so…hopeless. You’d only seen it once, and that was after Titan. He still struggled as did you, which was why you were back in the same bed at night, and you knew you couldn’t keep this up much longer. Neither of you.

“Yeah,” Peter said, his voice far away. “Yeah, Christmas is coming soon.”

You didn’t answer, only took a deep breath and let it out slowly through your nose. Your hands were shaking and you felt a bit dizzy. Stumbling, you hurried to sit down and drink from the water glass Peter had gotten for you. He didn’t move at the sight of you nearly collapsing into a chair, though, which made you start to worry.

“Pete?” No reply. His eyes stared blankly at the wall, lifeless. “Peter? Hey, you in there?”

He didn’t react, making your worry spike. You knew how bad his panic attacks could get, and while this kind wasn’t as physically taxing as the kind where he felt like all he could breathe in was ash, it was equally terrifying to witness.

“You’re in the apartment. You’re with me. I’m here. You’re solid, okay?” you said gently, reaching for his hand. He let you take it. “Peter, I’m right here-“

“Do you want a divorce?”

Silence. Your heart stopped beating and your entire body froze. Peter tightened his hold on your now slipping hand but kept his eyes trained on the wall, and that’s when you realized he hadn’t been having a panic attack at all. He’d just been letting that question—that horrid, awful question—bounce around his head and slowly creep to the tip of his tongue until it exited through his lips. No wonder he had looked so lifeless.

Your stomach flipped. Suddenly the stir fry didn’t seem as appetizing as before.

“W….what?” you whispered.

Peter looked down, finally away from the wall, then up at you. He went to say something then shut his mouth, closing his eyes as if he were in pain.

You really didn’t need Peter to repeat the question—you really didn’t want him to—but considering you still couldn’t form any other words that indicated so, you had to watch and listen as he did.

“I…do you want a divorce?” he said again, this time a little less sure but just as seriously.

The room began to spin a little, though you weren’t sure if it was because of the insane amount of pain you were in or because of the shock. Probably both.

Your heart may as well have stopped with all the beats it’d skipped and still was skipping. It was cracking—ripping right in half—making your entire being buzz in alarm and activate a fight or flight mode you hadn’t felt in a while—had had no reason to feel. Your stomach was turning, your hands were shaking, and your mouth was dry as you somehow rounded up enough of your brain to choke out, “Do you?”

Peter didn’t flinch at the question, which made you that much closer to retching in the nearest trash can. It was almost as if he’d been expecting this.

Just how long had he been preparing for this?

“Peter,” you said desperately, your voice cracking in the middle of it. “Answer me. Please.”

He opened his eyes at your squeezing of his hand and gave your locked palms a look you couldn’t quite put your finger on. There was obvious pain in his eyes as he raised them and placed a gentle kiss on the back of yours. “I-I love you,” he said, his voice wavering, and your heart dropped when he let go of your hand.

“Peter-“ you started, panic in your tone, but he didn’t let you complete your thought.

“But this—what we’re doing—it’s…it’s destroying us. I can’t keep sitting back and watching everything we’ve built crumble into…” Peter faltered, swallowing before going on. “…into dust. I think-I think that we both deserve happiness. And this isn’t it. I just…I know you’re mad at me and I want to fix it but I can’t, because I can’t promise you that I’ll never go on a mission again. Spider-Man means so much to me and to the people and I can’t just…I can’t promise that.” He paused, looking at you with the soft brown orbs you’d fallen in love with the minute they laid eyes on you. “I can promise that I love you with everything I have and that I always will, but I can’t…I can’t do this anymore.”

A panic you’d never felt clawed at you, tearing holes in your heart and your lungs and your soul, leaving you struggling for air like a fish out of water. Only—you knew how to breathe. You knew there was air to breathe. It was simple: inhale, exhale, inhale, exhale, inhale, exhale, over and over and over again. It shouldn’t be that hard.

You finally understood what Peter meant when he told you that having a panic attack was like suffocating against your own will—not drowning, because there was still air, and not choking, because there were no outside forces that were responsible for it. Suffocating, because you physically couldn’t breathe when you should be perfectly able—when everyone else was perfectly able.

Inhale, exhale. It was that simple. And yet, your lungs refused to take in any of the air you were so desperate for.

Despite your immense dizziness and slightly blackened vision—just how long had your lungs been empty?—you managed to stand and make your way to the nearest trash can.

You retched.

—

Neither of you brought the topic back up, not wanting a repeat of last time. Fortunately, this meant that the ‘D’ word was never spoken again. Unfortunately, this also meant that there was a surplus of words that needed to be said and weren’t, leading you further away from each other. You didn’t even speak anymore other than to remind one another of some event or appointment you had the next day. You were running on autopilot, relying on muscle memory to get you through each day. You were sure Peter felt the same.

You and Peter ended up splitting the team up and buying gifts for whoever was in your half (you ended up buying Steve’s), and while Peter got May and Happy their gifts, you got Pepper and the Barton family theirs. The Christmas decorations didn’t come out, there wasn’t any Christmas cookie dough in the fridge, and the Christmas tree never got picked from your favorite tree farm. No one ever came over—it was always to the compound or to May’s—so you didn’t have to worry about anyone noticing.

You still went to Sunday dinners together, and though you were never particularly hungry you ate until you were uncomfortably full on those days to make up for the diet you’d had the rest of the week. You and Peter found it was easier and less awkward if you split up at dinner, putting on the façade of needing to catch up with the girls and him the boys, you about any and all new developments in each one’s life and Peter about the latest technology Tony had been working with. That wasn’t to say the team didn’t catch on—after all, they were trained to pick up on these sort of things—but they left it alone for the most part (‘most part’ referring to the funny looks they sometimes gave one another), believing that by next week you’d have it all worked out.

But then one week passed, and then the next, and then the next.

And now it was Christmas. Things were as low as you thought it could possibly get with Peter and you were dying to fix it, but every time you thought you’d try you remembered how last time went and immediately lost every ounce of courage you’d managed to gather. Peter sometimes did the same, late at night when you were laying in bed with nothing to say. His jaw would open then snap shut a half a second later, and you didn’t have to ask any questions because you knew.

Peter was right: this wasn’t happiness. But he was wrong about you being mad at him. That had long passed, replaced by anxiety and despair. You weren’t mad. You actually weren’t sure if you ever were. Irritated, maybe, at most. Disappointed and betrayed seemed like more appropriate words for what you’d felt. But you still loved him; nothing had changed there. And Peter had openly confessed to still loving you (and that he always would), so you had hope. Some days the hope was hard to find, having been buried under a pile of heavy thoughts and emotions, but somehow it always worked its way back to the top, if only for a second. But a second was enough; it had to be. It had to be, or you would have been hopeless a long time ago.

“Is that everything?”

You nodded then frowned, looking around desperately. “Yeah, but-“

“I, uh, took your purse out to the car already. If that’s what you’re looking for,” Peter said quietly, rubbing the back of his neck. Your heart clenched.

“Yeah, that’s…” You cleared your throat, quickly looking away before he could see the tears forming in your eyes. “That’s what I was looking for.”

A beat of silence. Then two.

“Y/N, I-“

“Pete, I know where you’re going,” you weakly interrupted. “Please don’t. We-we have to go or we’ll be late.”

His lips sealed shut and he agreeably nodded, then ushered you both to the car. He still held the door open for you as you clambered in and made sure you were buckled in before taking off, and you had to pretend you were really interested in whatever was outside so he wouldn’t see the tears that had overflowed. You decided right then and there that being a girl had never sucked more. Damn hormones.

You clutched your purse the entire way upstate.

—

Neither of you made a move to get out of the car when you got to the compound, neither of you ready to go through yet another day of pretending everything was fine when it was really far from it.

Peter spoke first.

“Before we go in,” he said, his brows furrowed slightly and the corners of his mouth tilted down, “I need to ask you something and I need you to be honest with me about it.”

Your heart dropped, your mind replaying the same question he’d already asked you twice with a less than favorable outcome. Peter must have dissected the look on your face, though, and rushed to fix it.

“All things aside,” he quickly added, his eyes a bit wider now. “I just need to ask you something that’s been bothering me for a few weeks now, and I don’t think I can make it through Christmas without knowing the answer.”

You swallowed and held your purse tighter, but slowly nodded your agreement. Peter nodded too, then turned away to figure out how to ask what he wanted. It was a good minute before he faced you again, and the blatant concern in his eyes surprised you.

“Are you in trouble?”

You blinked. “Like…like with the law?”

“No.” Peter shook his head, then paused and gave you a second look. “But…wait, are you?”

“No, of course not!” you said, more confused than ever. “Peter, what do you mean, am I in trouble? Am I in trouble with who? With what? I don’t-“

“I don’t know!” he exclaimed, sighing and tugging at his curls. “With-with Spider-Man, or something!”

“Well, unless I somehow misread the past five years, I thought you were Spider-Man-“

“No! I mean, yes, I am, but I — that’s not what I meant!” Peter interrupted again, this time much more frustrated. He wasn’t looking at you now, his head instead aimed down at his lap. Your unspoken question was in the air—Then, what do you mean?—but it took Peter a little bit to get around to it. “You know how I said my senses were dialed up to 11? When I told you I was Spider-Man?”

Maybe if Peter didn’t look so distressed you’d think of a sarcastic quip to insert, something about how he thought you could forget that night, but you didn’t feel up to doing that, anyway. “Of course I do.”

“Well, you…you’ve been different lately,” Peter started.

“Yeah, well,” you said less harshly but more pointedly, “so have you, Peter.”

You could tell your words hurt him and you regretted becoming so defensive so fast. “That’s…that’s not what I meant,” Peter weakly said.

You resorted to another bout of silence—one full of tension.

“Peter, you’re going to have to explain,” you said eventually.

He sighed and lifted his head, staring out the windshield. “Whenever we’re in the same room, the hairs on the back of my neck tingle and I can just…it’s like I can sense something’s wrong but I don’t know what it is. It’s not exactly my spidey sense because I don’t go into fight-or-flight or feel like I’m in danger, it’s just different because something with you is different. Off. You look the same but there’s something off with everything else—like your scent. I mean, you smell almost exactly the same so maybe I’m just imagining it, and I’m sure I only noticed the difference because of my spidey sense going off, but my point is-” He paused to catch his breath. “I just…I need to know if you’re in trouble.” he continued, more softly than before. “If someone figured out who I am and is using you to get to me or-or something. It’s been driving me insane.”

Peter was wringing his fingers, something you knew he did when he felt anxious. You swallowed hard and reached over to place your hand atop his. His fingers stilled.

“I’m not in trouble, Pete,” you whispered. “I promise.”

He turned to you again, searching your eyes. He must have found what he was looking for, as soon after he breathed a small sigh of relief and his shoulders dropped. “Okay. Okay, that’s good. I’ll just…talk to Tony or someone about my spidey sense—call this time a misfire and see if we can figure it out.”

Peter went on to mumble about the so-called ‘misfire’ and probable causes behind it. You couldn’t make out half the words he was saying, but from what you could he seemed to be talking in circles, always landing back at square one. He seemed a bit frustrated.

You went back to holding your purse tightly to you, and an array of thoughts went through your head that subsequently caused you to take a deep breath and interrupt him.

“Peter.” He stopped mumbling and immediately trained his eyes on you. It was only then that you realized just how dark his bags were underneath them; no, you hadn’t been sleeping well either, but Peter looked like he hadn’t slept in days. You couldn’t help but wonder if it was because of his spidey sense constantly going off around you. Another breath. “Peter, I think I might know why-“

You never got to finish.

—

title: Valentine’s Day (Starker)
body:
This is for day 2 of the StarkerValentine2019 tag.

Prompt 2: Gifts.

Warnings: Only sickly sweet fluff, if you guys can handle that ;)

It was Tony and Peter’s fifth Valentine’s Day together.  It wasn’t really Tony’s favourite holiday.  They didn’t usually make a spectacle of the event – everything was ridiculously overpriced, and while that wasn’t a problem for Tony, it bugged him because he knew Peter would want to try and do something for him but he wouldn’t be able to afford it.  To make matters worse, Peter never accepted money when Tony offered. So usually, Valentine’s Day was just another day on the calendar for them.

This year, however, Peter had asked Tony out on a date.  Tony had initially been pretty surprised by the gesture, but then when he thought about it he’d realised that his boyfriend had always been a hopeless romantic, and now he actually had a good, stable job. So Tony said yes, without hesitation.

They found themselves at a small Italian restaurant that they’d walked past many times before, but they’d never been inside.  It was quaint, romantic.  Tony would have liked anything that Peter had picked out, but this little place was so cosy and secluded, and the smile on Peter’s face when they walked in made Tony’s heart race.

They sat down and the waiter offered them a menu.  Tony’s eyes immediately dropped to the prices.  This restaurant was far too expensive for Peter, but he didn’t quite know how to say it without offending him.

“Order anything you want,” Peter said, taking Tony’s hand over the table.  “I mean it. Starters, main course, dessert. Anything you want in between.  Get the most expensive bottle of champagne if you want.  Okay?”

Tony rubbed his thumb over the soft skin of Peter’s hand and exhaled slowly.  “We could have gone to McDonald’s and I’d still love you as much.  You didn’t have to-”

“-Shush.  I didn’t spend ages trying to find the perfect restaurant for you to turn around and say you’d rather be at McDonald’s,” Peter said, nudging the menu closer to Tony.  “Pick anything.  Please?”

Tony glanced up at Peter, and the look in his eyes was enough to make Tony’s heart melt.  He looked so happy, so excited for Tony to pick something, and to be able to treat Tony – how we was going to do that, Tony still had no idea. “Fine,” Tony said softly, breaking his gaze and looking down to read the menu.

Tony ended up skipping starters and going for the cheapest pizza on the menu.  Peter had been adamant that he didn’t have to go for the cheap meals, but Tony refused to go for anything over 15$.  They’d gone for a bottle of white wine, that they shared.  All in all, it had been a pretty great night.  

By the time they finished their desserts, Tony was a little bit buzzed from the wine since he hadn’t really eaten a lot that day. Peter, on the other hand, seemed really tipsy.  He wasn’t speaking nonsense or swaying or slurring his words, but he was acting very nervous.  Tony hadn’t seen him like this since, well, since the very early days of them dating.  It was cute.

The bill came, and Peter snatched it up before Tony could get a glimpse of the price.  Tony watched as Peter smiled at the waiter and said he’d pay by cash.

Peter pulled a couple of hundred dollar bills out of his wallet, and Tony raised his eyebrows.  Where had he gotten the money from?  He was about to open his mouth to ask, but Peter suddenly stood up and held a hand out for Tony to take.

“Let’s go,” Peter said.  “I want to take you somewhere.”

Tony took Peter’s hand and followed him out of the restaurant. They walked for a while in comfortable silence, and then Tony realised he hadn’t thanked Peter for the meal.  Idiot, he berated himself.

“Thanks so much for the meal, baby,” Tony said, wrapping an arm around Peter’s waist as they walked.  It was cold out, and Peter leaned into Tony’s touch.

“Did you like it?” Peter asked, glancing up at Tony with a curious look in his soft brown eyes.

Tony held Peter closer to him and smiled.  “I loved it.”

Peter’s smile grew, and with that Tony stopped, stepping in front of Peter and wrapping his other arm around the younger man’s waist.

“Why are you stopping?” Peter asked, shivering slightly at the cold.  It was just beginning to snow, and Tony couldn’t ask for better timing if he tried.

“You smiled and I-” Tony started, lifting a hand up to caress Peter’s cheek softly.  “-I needed to kiss you.”

Peter only smiled more.  “So what are you waiting for?”

Tony closed the gap between them with a slow, tender kiss. Peter sighed contently against Tony’s lips and pushed himself closer to Tony, wrapping both his arms around his neck. Tony deepened the kiss, wishing it could last forever.  This moment was perfect.  God, he loved Peter – more than anything.  Their bodies were pressed together, fingers tangled in each other’s hair, lips crashing together now in a desperate need to feel only each other.

When they eventually broke apart for air, they stayed only inches apart, foreheads pressed together.  Peter exhaled, the cold making his breath visible between them. They stared at each other, getting lost in each other’s eyes.

“Peter, I-”

“-Marry me,” Peter whispered, not taking his eyes off Tony’s. “Please, please marry me.”

“I- for real?” Tony asked, holding onto Peter more tightly. He couldn’t believe what was happening. He really hadn’t expected that.  Was Peter really proposing to him?  It fit.  The fancy restaurant, Valentine’s Day, the nervousness…

“For real, I- I got you a ring, um, hold on,” Peter stammered, releasing one of his hands from around Tony’s neck and fumbling around in his jacket pocket for something.  He brought his other hand down and then carefully got down on one knee.  “Let me do this right, okay?”

Tony blinked down at him, but he couldn’t find the words.  He nodded, unable to keep the smile from his face.

Peter shakily brought the box up and opened it, revealing a beautiful ring that was exactly to Tony’s taste.  It wasn’t too over-the-top, not girly, not even too plain.  It was just perfect, and it definitely wasn’t cheap.  Tony knew a lot about jewellery, and this was the real deal.

“Tony, you’re the best thing that’s ever happened to me. You make me smile when I’m feeling at my worst, and you make me laugh when I just want to curl up and cry.  You bring light to my life, and you make me happy to be alive.  I, uh, well… I actually had a whole speech prepared and I’ve totally forgotten it so… there goes that,” Peter said, laughing nervously. Tony brought his hands out to steady Peter’s shaky hands.  “But what I’m really trying to ask you is… well… Tony Stark, will you marry me?”

For a split second, Tony thought he’d mess with Peter and say something stupid, but the look in Peter’s eyes made it impossible.  How could he say anything other than ‘yes’ to the pure, beautiful angel that was kneeling before him asking him to be his forever?  Tony grinned down at him.  “Of course I’ll marry you.”

“You will?!” Peter asked, getting up quickly, looking utterly relieved.

“I will,” Tony repeated, holding his hand out expectantly.

Peter made an excited sound and pulled the ring out of the box, slowly sliding it onto Tony’s left ring-finger.

“It suits you,” Peter said, admiring the ring on Tony’s hand and then staring up at his face with adoration. “We’re getting married!”

Tony pulled Peter closer and kissed the top of his forehead. “How’d you afford all this?”

“I’ve been saving for years,” Peter said quietly, resting his head against Tony’s chest.  “All the money I could save, I put it away.”

“You didn’t have to do this-”

“-Tony, I know that,” Peter said, holding onto him tighter. “But I wanted to.”

Tony kissed the top of his head.  “I love you, you know that?”

“I know that,” Peter said with a smile.  

And so, Valentine’s Day was now Tony’s favourite holiday.

This year, however, Peter had asked Tony out on a date.  Tony had initially been pretty surprised by the gesture, but then when he thought about it he’d realised that his boyfriend had always been a hopeless romantic, and now he actually had a good, stable job. So Tony said yes, without hesitation.

They found themselves at a small Italian restaurant that they’d walked past many times before, but they’d never been inside.  It was quaint, romantic.  Tony would have liked anything that Peter had picked out, but this little place was so cosy and secluded, and the smile on Peter’s face when they walked in made Tony’s heart race.

They sat down and the waiter offered them a menu.  Tony’s eyes immediately dropped to the prices.  This restaurant was far too expensive for Peter, but he didn’t quite know how to say it without offending him.

“Order anything you want,” Peter said, taking Tony’s hand over the table.  “I mean it. Starters, main course, dessert. Anything you want in between.  Get the most expensive bottle of champagne if you want.  Okay?”

Tony rubbed his thumb over the soft skin of Peter’s hand and exhaled slowly.  “We could have gone to McDonald’s and I’d still love you as much.  You didn’t have to-”

“-Shush.  I didn’t spend ages trying to find the perfect restaurant for you to turn around and say you’d rather be at McDonald’s,” Peter said, nudging the menu closer to Tony.  “Pick anything.  Please?”

Tony glanced up at Peter, and the look in his eyes was enough to make Tony’s heart melt.  He looked so happy, so excited for Tony to pick something, and to be able to treat Tony – how we was going to do that, Tony still had no idea. “Fine,” Tony said softly, breaking his gaze and looking down to read the menu.

Tony ended up skipping starters and going for the cheapest pizza on the menu.  Peter had been adamant that he didn’t have to go for the cheap meals, but Tony refused to go for anything over 15$.  They’d gone for a bottle of white wine, that they shared.  All in all, it had been a pretty great night.  

By the time they finished their desserts, Tony was a little bit buzzed from the wine since he hadn’t really eaten a lot that day. Peter, on the other hand, seemed really tipsy.  He wasn’t speaking nonsense or swaying or slurring his words, but he was acting very nervous.  Tony hadn’t seen him like this since, well, since the very early days of them dating.  It was cute.

The bill came, and Peter snatched it up before Tony could get a glimpse of the price.  Tony watched as Peter smiled at the waiter and said he’d pay by cash.

Peter pulled a couple of hundred dollar bills out of his wallet, and Tony raised his eyebrows.  Where had he gotten the money from?  He was about to open his mouth to ask, but Peter suddenly stood up and held a hand out for Tony to take.

“Let’s go,” Peter said.  “I want to take you somewhere.”

“Thanks so much for the meal, baby,” Tony said, wrapping an arm around Peter’s waist as they walked.  It was cold out, and Peter leaned into Tony’s touch.

“Did you like it?” Peter asked, glancing up at Tony with a curious look in his soft brown eyes.

blog.title: ¡requests are open so pop that ask in!
blog.description: Majka | she/her | bi | casually in love with everything | i try to write stuff but i need motivation | masterlist

body:
Be My Valentine? |Peter Parker|

♡VALENTINES BLURB♡

Word Count: 564

Requested: nah

Warnings: none, fuff?

A/n: THIS IS FLUFF. I’m sorry it’s short, but I had no time to write. Tell me what do you think. Oh, and don’t forget to request something for my birthday sleepover. HAPPY VALENTINES TO THOSE WHO CELEBRATE ALONE AND TO THOSE WHO CELEBRATE WITH THEIR SIGNIFICANT OTHERS.💕💕

English is not my first language.

🐝masterlist in my bio🐝

REQUEST IF YOU WANT MORE

Gif is not mine. Credits to the owner.

LOOK AT THIS SMILE!

Peter was nervous. Well, more nervous than usual. This was the day he waited for such a long time. He was dressed in his best shirt and pants, holding a bouquet of red roses. His fingers were hurting from gripping too hard on the thorns and his lip felt sore from bitting it to hard. Even though Peter didn’t feel comfortable he didn’t care. It was very special day for him. He had been planning it for months. Everything was supposed to be perfect.

He was going to ask you out.

It was Valentine’s day and he finally got the guts to do it. He planned to ask Mr Start to drive him to school this day in one of his new cars to impress you. He wanted to buy the best suit, rent a orchestra to play love songs and buy the biggest flower bouquet of them all. He was willing to spend all his money just to give you the best impression of himself on this special day.

It didn’t work out though. Mr Stark wasn’t answering his phone (probably being too busy planning his own date with Pepper or building another Iron Man suit), all the orchestras have been rented a year ago, he couldn’t affor a decent suit, and the florist had only one miserable bouquet left. It was a total disaster and Peter knew it. The wort thing was he couldn’t do anything about it. Sure, he could have just show up in his Spiderman suit but then how would he know you really liked him?

‘Just be yourself, Pete. She’ll like you’ Aunt May advised him while he was standing in front of the mirror trying to convince himself it’s not the end of the world. It was easy to say for a adult woman. Peter was certain (Y/N) wouldn’t like his dorky self.

Yet he did it. He risked everything and decided he is going to do it. There was nothing to lose, right? Well, maybe exept this not-so-decent-looking roses he was just holding while waiting for you to come. Peter’s eyes were wandering all over the corridor trying to spot you.

And then he saw you. The most amazing girl he has ever seen.

You were walking alone with books in your arms. You were wearing a simple white dress, your hair put in a loose braid. Peter thought you looked absolutely stunning.

He was so hypnotized by your beauty he almost forgot to catch you and ask you out.

Bitting his lip even more he slowly approached your locker where you were currently taking out your textbooks. He took a deep breath and gently patted your arm to get your attention. Not seeing him you jumped and squealed quietly in surprise.

'Oh God! I-I didn’t mean t-to scare you! I’m so sorry’ Peter apologized quickly.

'It’s okay, Pete. I just wasn’t expecting you that’s all’ you smiled softly waving your hand. Then you noticed the flowers he was holding.

'Anyways what’s up? Got any Valentine’s plans?’ you said pointing at the bouquet.

Peters eyes windened. He cleared his throat and looked into your eyes.

He had been planning it for months. Everything was supposed to be perfect.

He was going to ask you out.

It was Valentine’s day and he finally got the guts to do it. He planned to ask Mr Start to drive him to school this day in one of his new cars to impress you. He wanted to buy the best suit, rent a orchestra to play love songs and buy the biggest flower bouquet of them all. He was willing to spend all his money just to give you the best impression of himself on this special day.

It didn’t work out though. Mr Stark wasn’t answering his phone (probably being too busy planning his own date with Pepper or building another Iron Man suit), all the orchestras have been rented a year ago, he couldn’t affor a decent suit, and the florist had only one miserable bouquet left. It was a total disaster and Peter knew it. The wort thing was he couldn’t do anything about it. Sure, he could have just show up in his Spiderman suit but then how would he know you really liked him?

‘Just be yourself, Pete. She’ll like you’ Aunt May advised him while he was standing in front of the mirror trying to convince himself it’s not the end of the world. It was easy to say for a adult woman. Peter was certain (Y/N) wouldn’t like his dorky self.

And then he saw you. The most amazing girl he has ever seen.

You were walking alone with books in your arms. You were wearing a simple white dress, your hair put in a loose braid. Peter thought you looked absolutely stunning.

He was so hypnotized by your beauty he almost forgot to catch you and ask you out.

Bitting his lip even more he slowly approached your locker where you were currently taking out your textbooks. He took a deep breath and gently patted your arm to get your attention. Not seeing him you jumped and squealed quietly in surprise.

'Oh God! I-I didn’t mean t-to scare you! I’m so sorry’ Peter apologized quickly.

'It’s okay, Pete. I just wasn’t expecting you that’s all’ you smiled softly waving your hand. Then you noticed the flowers he was holding.

'Anyways what’s up? Got any Valentine’s plans?’ you said pointing at the bouquet.

'Um, yes accually. I wanted to- Erm, I mean-’ he rambled.

title: The Firsts and the Lasts
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2GJIXPV

by Violet_arabian

Peter managed to survive the Vulture, get in good graces with Tony Stark, and finish the school year in a neat bow. Finally, his life as Spider-Man had begun. Sure, he still took care of petty theft and the occasional grand theft, but he had also been acknowledged. Which meant that there were more big-time baddies to fight and wounds to tend. Yet, for some reason, no one told him that villains or anti-heroes would be so infuriatingly persistent.
From the start of his senior year to the next three chapters of his life, Peter faces dark alleyways, high rooftops, close calls, and family time. All while dealing with Deadpool, unaware of the heavy and dark future looming above them.

title: Hell's Frozen (I'm Getting You Out)
body:
read it on the AO3 at http://bit.ly/2GGsEDc

by josywbu

“Mr. Stark?” he asked and his voice was shaking, he sounded afraid all of the sudden and Tony hated it. Who the hell dared to scare his child like that?

“Daddy?”

His thoughts came to a screeching halt when his little girl appeared next to Peter, holding on to his legs that were still clad in the Spidersuit. And it didn’t make sense. Because Morgan had never gotten to meet her big brother, had never gotten to cling to him or hide behind him when she was scared.

“You have to let the stones go.“

summary:
For Valentine’s Day, Peter and DUM-E go through the Compound and hand out Valentines to everyone.
Tony, looking at what DUM-E...
body:
For Valentine’s Day, Peter and DUM-E go through the Compound and hand out Valentines to everyone.

Tony, looking at what DUM-E dropped in his hand: What’s this?

Peter: It’s his Valentine’s gift for you!

Tony: It’s a bolt.

Peter, wrapping his arm around DUM-E: You’re hurting his feelings! What did you expect him to do? Order something off of Amazon?

Tony: I-

title: A Little Effort (t.h.)
body:
Summary: you had planned a romantic evening for you and tom but his groupchat with harrison and jacob has him preoccupied.

A/N: another imagine that has a proposal in it 😂 i love those kinds of imagines, i think they’re SO cute soooo enjoy

Warnings: mentions of blood

You had been planning a Valentine’s Day dinner for you and Tom for weeks. You wanted it to be perfect, especially since he was home a lot more now.

Getting reservations at one of the nicest restaurants in London was a struggle but you pulled the ‘this is for Tom Holland’ card. You even went so far as to get a new red dress to wear. You only hoped it didn’t go unnoticed.

You and Tom were sitting at the table, eyes scanning over the menu, when Tom’s phone buzzed on the table. You scowled as he picked it up to see who it was. A toothy grin appeared on his face and you had no doubt it was from Harrison.

He typed back a reply and you hoped he would leave it at that but as he kept tapping at the screen, you knew it was a groupchat.

“Tom,” You started, trying to get his attention. “Are we going to order or at least have a meaningful conversation?” You asked him. “Hm? Yeah, babe, get whatever you want.” Tom replied, still looking at his phone.

At that point, the anger and annoyance you felt was practically radiating off of you. You clenched your jaw as the waiter came around and you had it. “I’m sorry, but we had a family emergency come up and have to leave.” You lied.

And Tom didn’t even notice you were planning on leaving. Once the waiter left the table, you grabbed your purse and your coat and stood up, putting on your coat.

“Wait, what are you doing?” Tom asked, finally looking up from his phone. “Oh so now you notice? Well, since you’re enjoying your conversation a lot more than this dinner I planned for us, you can spend Valentine’s Day with Harrison and Jacob.” You replied before stomping out of the restaurant.

Tom sat there for a couple of minutes before standing up to follow after you. “Babe, wait!” He called as he was trying to catch up with you. But once you got into the Uber you ordered, he was too late.

**

You arrived home and took your heels off by the door. Planning that dinner for you and Tom took way more work than he probably thought.

Walking into the kitchen, you saw Tessa lying on the couch, unbothered by your presence. Grabbing a bottle of champagne from the wine rack, you popped open the top of it not even bothering to use a glass.

“Happy Valentine’s Day to me.” You mutter before taking a big swig from the bottle. You heard the front door open and rolled your eyes knowing it was Tom.

“Y/N?” He called. Tom turned the corner into the kitchen and saw you standing there, leaning against the counter, with a bottle of champagne in your hand.

He finally got a good look at your appearance and he wanted to say you looked beautiful but he didn’t think that moment was the right time. “Can we talk about why you’re mad?” Tom asked you.

“So now you want to talk to me. You want to talk about why I’m mad? Well, Tom, I’m mad because I put so much effort into planning out the perfect Valentine’s Day dinner for us and you think a stupid groupchat is more important than that.” You snapped.

“It was just dinner, love, we still have the rest of the night.” Tom said. “It wasn’t just dinner! I got us a reservation at one of the best restaurants in London! Do you know how difficult that was? I bought a brand new dress for you! Hell, I even bought new lingerie to try to make this night special but you couldn’t care less!” You yelled, waving your hands around with the bottle still in your grasp.

That part started to make Tom nervous because he didn’t want you to accidentally break the bottle and hurt yourself.

“God, Tom, you could have put in a little effort into this night. But instead, you decided that Harrison and Jacob were more important.” You added, slamming the bottle onto the counter.

When you did, the bottom of the bottle shattered and glass fell onto the ground and champagne spilled everywhere.

“Shit, Y/N.” Tom muttered walking towards you. “I got it.” You told him, holding your hand in front of you, signaling for him to stay back. You got onto your knees to begin to pick up the glass. “Y/N, let me help you before you cut yourself.” Tom said.

You ignored him and continued to pick up the glass. “Y/N,” Tom started. “What?” You snapped back, looking up at him. When you weren’t looking at him, it just seemed as if you were angry but once you made eye contact with him, he saw your makeup was smudged and your cheeks were stained with tears. If he wasn’t guilty before, he was when he saw you had been crying.

Tom knew you weren’t one to cry over just a normal dinner or to cry over any other day. So you crying because of that, means that it was important to you. 

When you knew Tom wasn’t going to say anything, you scoffed and returned your focus back to the glass. But the tears made your vision blurry and as you picked up a larger piece, it cut the middle of your palm. 

You hissed in pain and dropped the piece of glass quickly. You stood up and reached for paper towels when you felt Tom’s hand on your waist. Blood was dripping down you arm as you tried to make the bleeding stop. 

“Y/N, are you okay?” He asked. “I’m fine.” You muttered. “No you’re not. You can go back to being mad at me after we’ve cleaned this up.” Tom told you, a sternness in his voice. 

The rational part of you knew he was right, so you let him take your hand and run it under the warm water. You sat on the edge of the counter, as Tom went back and forth between your hand and the first aid kit.

You watched as he tended to your injuries and your eyes couldn’t help but water. You just wanted the night to be perfect and it’s all gone to hell. 

A tear fell onto your lap, catching Tom’s attention. He looked up at you, only to have you lift your head up and look at the ceiling. “Love, can you just talk to me without yelling?” He asked, using his thumb to wipe the tear off your cheek. 

“The last two years for Valentine’s Day, we were never able to spend the day together. We couldn’t do anything special for each other and I just wanted this year to be different. But then we were at dinner and you were sitting on your phone talking to Harrison and you weren’t even paying attention to me. It may have seemed like just another dinner to you but to me it was supposed to be amazing.” You said sniffling at the end of your rant. 

Tom closed his eyes tightly as he was still working on your hand. “I am so sorry, Y/N. I don’t have an excuse for acting like an ass.” Tom said, his own eyes beginning to water. 

When he had finished wrapping up your hand, he continued to hold it, both of your hands resting on your lap. 

“I’m sorry if I made it seem as if I didn’t appreciate what you did tonight. I love you so much, Y/N and I appreciate everything you do for me. Putting up with me and Harrison when we’re watching football. Or when I’m too lazy to take Tessa out and you offer to do it. Or when you’re just being you.” He added. 

You looked up at him when he placed a hand on your cheek. “I love you too, Tom.” You said quietly. “I’ll make this up to you, I promise.” Tom said quickly. “No, it’s okay. I’m probably just overreacting. I think i’m probably going to head to bed.” You told him as you got down from the counter. You were just tired of fighting with him and wanted it to be over.

“Okay, babe. I’ll clean this up and I’ll be right up.” Tom told you.You gave him a sad smile before placing a gentle kiss on his cheek. 

When you left the room, Tom ran his hands through his hair and sighed. “I’m so stupid.” He said to himself.

He never wanted to make you feel less important than you were. The truth was, he had something planned that he was going to do at home but he got so caught up texting Harrison and Jacob about it, he forgot he was at dinner. Grabbing a broom and dust pan, Tom dialed Harrison’s number.

“Hello?” He answered. “I am so beyond mad at you right now.” Tom said to his best friend. “What did I do?” Harrison asked. “Because you kept texting me at dinner, Y/N is pissed at me. Me texting you back made her feel as if I didn’t care about the night she planned.” Tom explained. “Shit. So you didn’t ask her?” Harrison questioned. “No, I didn’t ask her. But i’m going to do it tomorrow. That’s why I need your help.” Tom said. “Okay, what can I do?” Harrison replied.

You got into the room and changed into your pajamas, before climbing into bed. Soon after, Tessa walked into the room as well. “Hey, Tess.” You said to the dog as she climbed up on the bed and curled up next to you. Quickly, your eyes began to feel heavy and you fell asleep.

**

The next morning, you awoke to an empty bed, except for Tessa. You didn’t even feel Tom come to bed the night before so you began to get worried. You removed the comforter and climbed out of bed to go see where Tom was.

Walking down the stairs, you heard music playing softly from the kitchen. You stepped into the room and saw Tom standing shirtless at the stove making waffles. “Tom, what are you doing?” You asked with a small chuckle.

He turned around and gave you a big smile. “Good morning, love. I wanted to make you breakfast and make up for ruining our night.” He told you. “It’s okay. Really, I’m over it.” You said. “But i’m not. I never want to make you feel less important than you are. Because you’re the most important person in my life.” Tom retorted. You couldn’t say anything when Tom left the kitchen and walked into the living room.

When he returned, he had a black box full of flowers and he set them down on the table, before pulling the chair out for you.

You sat down in front of the flowers and grabbed the card from the top.

“Y/N, you are the love of my life and the best person I’ve ever had the pleasure of knowing. I couldn’t imagine living my life without you. I’m so sorry for messing up the evening you had planned for us and I’m going to make sure I make it up to you.” You read out loud.

You quickly wiped the tear that fell from your eyes, though they were happy tears. “Which is why I have something to ask you.” You continued. You looked to your left where Tom was and saw him down on one knee with a black box in his hands.

With wide eyes, you set the card down and looked at Tom. “The card says it all, love. So, what do you say? Will you marry me?” He asked.

At first, you physically couldn’t form your response so you had to stick with nodding your head rapidly. Tom smiled up at you as he took the ring from the box and slid it on to your finger.

You practically tackled Tom to the floor when you threw your arms around him. “I love you. I love you so much.” You said into the crook of his neck. “And I love you, Y/N. I always will.” Tom said, kissing the top of your head.

February 14th was supposed to be a memorable day for the both of you but February 15th quickly became your favorite day.

You sat down in front of the flowers and grabbed the card from the top.

“Y/N, you are the love of my life and the best person I’ve ever had the pleasure of knowing. I couldn’t imagine living my life without you. I’m so sorry for messing up the evening you had planned for us and I’m going to make sure I make it up to you.” You read out loud.

You quickly wiped the tear that fell from your eyes, though they were happy tears. “Which is why I have something to ask you.” You continued. You looked to your left where Tom was and saw him down on one knee with a black box in his hands.

With wide eyes, you set the card down and looked at Tom. “The card says it all, love. So, what do you say? Will you marry me?” He asked.

At first, you physically couldn’t form your response so you had to stick with nodding your head rapidly. Tom smiled up at you as he took the ring from the box and slid it on to your finger.

You practically tackled Tom to the floor when you threw your arms around him. “I love you. I love you so much.” You said into the crook of his neck. “And I love you, Y/N. I always will.” Tom said, kissing the top of your head.

February 14th was supposed to be a memorable day for the both of you but February 15th quickly became your favorite day.
trail.content:
Summary: you had planned a romantic evening for you and tom but his groupchat with harrison and jacob has him preoccupied.

A/N: another imagine that has a proposal in it 😂 i love those kinds of imagines, i think they’re SO cute soooo enjoy

Warnings: mentions of blood

You had been planning a Valentine’s Day dinner for you and Tom for weeks. You wanted it to be perfect, especially since he was home a lot more now.

Getting reservations at one of the nicest restaurants in London was a struggle but you pulled the ‘this is for Tom Holland’ card. You even went so far as to get a new red dress to wear. You only hoped it didn’t go unnoticed.

You and Tom were sitting at the table, eyes scanning over the menu, when Tom’s phone buzzed on the table. You scowled as he picked it up to see who it was. A toothy grin appeared on his face and you had no doubt it was from Harrison.

He typed back a reply and you hoped he would leave it at that but as he kept tapping at the screen, you knew it was a groupchat.

“Tom,” You started, trying to get his attention. “Are we going to order or at least have a meaningful conversation?” You asked him. “Hm? Yeah, babe, get whatever you want.” Tom replied, still looking at his phone.

At that point, the anger and annoyance you felt was practically radiating off of you. You clenched your jaw as the waiter came around and you had it. “I’m sorry, but we had a family emergency come up and have to leave.” You lied.

And Tom didn’t even notice you were planning on leaving. Once the waiter left the table, you grabbed your purse and your coat and stood up, putting on your coat.

“Wait, what are you doing?” Tom asked, finally looking up from his phone. “Oh so now you notice? Well, since you’re enjoying your conversation a lot more than this dinner I planned for us, you can spend Valentine’s Day with Harrison and Jacob.” You replied before stomping out of the restaurant.

Tom sat there for a couple of minutes before standing up to follow after you. “Babe, wait!” He called as he was trying to catch up with you. But once you got into the Uber you ordered, he was too late.

**

You arrived home and took your heels off by the door. Planning that dinner for you and Tom took way more work than he probably thought.

Walking into the kitchen, you saw Tessa lying on the couch, unbothered by your presence. Grabbing a bottle of champagne from the wine rack, you popped open the top of it not even bothering to use a glass.

“Happy Valentine’s Day to me.” You mutter before taking a big swig from the bottle. You heard the front door open and rolled your eyes knowing it was Tom.

“Y/N?” He called. Tom turned the corner into the kitchen and saw you standing there, leaning against the counter, with a bottle of champagne in your hand.

He finally got a good look at your appearance and he wanted to say you looked beautiful but he didn’t think that moment was the right time. “Can we talk about why you’re mad?” Tom asked you.

“So now you want to talk to me. You want to talk about why I’m mad? Well, Tom, I’m mad because I put so much effort into planning out the perfect Valentine’s Day dinner for us and you think a stupid groupchat is more important than that.” You snapped.

“It was just dinner, love, we still have the rest of the night.” Tom said. “It wasn’t just dinner! I got us a reservation at one of the best restaurants in London! Do you know how difficult that was? I bought a brand new dress for you! Hell, I even bought new lingerie to try to make this night special but you couldn’t care less!” You yelled, waving your hands around with the bottle still in your grasp.

That part started to make Tom nervous because he didn’t want you to accidentally break the bottle and hurt yourself.

“God, Tom, you could have put in a little effort into this night. But instead, you decided that Harrison and Jacob were more important.” You added, slamming the bottle onto the counter.

When you did, the bottom of the bottle shattered and glass fell onto the ground and champagne spilled everywhere.

“Shit, Y/N.” Tom muttered walking towards you. “I got it.” You told him, holding your hand in front of you, signaling for him to stay back. You got onto your knees to begin to pick up the glass. “Y/N, let me help you before you cut yourself.” Tom said.

You ignored him and continued to pick up the glass. “Y/N,” Tom started. “What?” You snapped back, looking up at him. When you weren’t looking at him, it just seemed as if you were angry but once you made eye contact with him, he saw your makeup was smudged and your cheeks were stained with tears. If he wasn’t guilty before, he was when he saw you had been crying.

Tom knew you weren’t one to cry over just a normal dinner or to cry over any other day. So you crying because of that, means that it was important to you. 

When you knew Tom wasn’t going to say anything, you scoffed and returned your focus back to the glass. But the tears made your vision blurry and as you picked up a larger piece, it cut the middle of your palm. 

You hissed in pain and dropped the piece of glass quickly. You stood up and reached for paper towels when you felt Tom’s hand on your waist. Blood was dripping down you arm as you tried to make the bleeding stop. 

“Y/N, are you okay?” He asked. “I’m fine.” You muttered. “No you’re not. You can go back to being mad at me after we’ve cleaned this up.” Tom told you, a sternness in his voice. 

The rational part of you knew he was right, so you let him take your hand and run it under the warm water. You sat on the edge of the counter, as Tom went back and forth between your hand and the first aid kit.

You watched as he tended to your injuries and your eyes couldn’t help but water. You just wanted the night to be perfect and it’s all gone to hell. 

A tear fell onto your lap, catching Tom’s attention. He looked up at you, only to have you lift your head up and look at the ceiling. “Love, can you just talk to me without yelling?” He asked, using his thumb to wipe the tear off your cheek. 

“The last two years for Valentine’s Day, we were never able to spend the day together. We couldn’t do anything special for each other and I just wanted this year to be different. But then we were at dinner and you were sitting on your phone talking to Harrison and you weren’t even paying attention to me. It may have seemed like just another dinner to you but to me it was supposed to be amazing.” You said sniffling at the end of your rant. 

Tom closed his eyes tightly as he was still working on your hand. “I am so sorry, Y/N. I don’t have an excuse for acting like an ass.” Tom said, his own eyes beginning to water. 

When he had finished wrapping up your hand, he continued to hold it, both of your hands resting on your lap. 

“I’m sorry if I made it seem as if I didn’t appreciate what you did tonight. I love you so much, Y/N and I appreciate everything you do for me. Putting up with me and Harrison when we’re watching football. Or when I’m too lazy to take Tessa out and you offer to do it. Or when you’re just being you.” He added. 

You looked up at him when he placed a hand on your cheek. “I love you too, Tom.” You said quietly. “I’ll make this up to you, I promise.” Tom said quickly. “No, it’s okay. I’m probably just overreacting. I think i’m probably going to head to bed.” You told him as you got down from the counter. You were just tired of fighting with him and wanted it to be over.

“Okay, babe. I’ll clean this up and I’ll be right up.” Tom told you.You gave him a sad smile before placing a gentle kiss on his cheek. 

When you left the room, Tom ran his hands through his hair and sighed. “I’m so stupid.” He said to himself.

He never wanted to make you feel less important than you were. The truth was, he had something planned that he was going to do at home but he got so caught up texting Harrison and Jacob about it, he forgot he was at dinner. Grabbing a broom and dust pan, Tom dialed Harrison’s number.

“Hello?” He answered. “I am so beyond mad at you right now.” Tom said to his best friend. “What did I do?” Harrison asked. “Because you kept texting me at dinner, Y/N is pissed at me. Me texting you back made her feel as if I didn’t care about the night she planned.” Tom explained. “Shit. So you didn’t ask her?” Harrison questioned. “No, I didn’t ask her. But i’m going to do it tomorrow. That’s why I need your help.” Tom said. “Okay, what can I do?” Harrison replied.

You got into the room and changed into your pajamas, before climbing into bed. Soon after, Tessa walked into the room as well. “Hey, Tess.” You said to the dog as she climbed up on the bed and curled up next to you. Quickly, your eyes began to feel heavy and you fell asleep.

**

The next morning, you awoke to an empty bed, except for Tessa. You didn’t even feel Tom come to bed the night before so you began to get worried. You removed the comforter and climbed out of bed to go see where Tom was.

Walking down the stairs, you heard music playing softly from the kitchen. You stepped into the room and saw Tom standing shirtless at the stove making waffles. “Tom, what are you doing?” You asked with a small chuckle.

He turned around and gave you a big smile. “Good morning, love. I wanted to make you breakfast and make up for ruining our night.” He told you. “It’s okay. Really, I’m over it.” You said. “But i’m not. I never want to make you feel less important than you are. Because you’re the most important person in my life.” Tom retorted. You couldn’t say anything when Tom left the kitchen and walked into the living room.

When he returned, he had a black box full of flowers and he set them down on the table, before pulling the chair out for you.

You sat down in front of the flowers and grabbed the card from the top.

“Y/N, you are the love of my life and the best person I’ve ever had the pleasure of knowing. I couldn’t imagine living my life without you. I’m so sorry for messing up the evening you had planned for us and I’m going to make sure I make it up to you.” You read out loud.

You quickly wiped the tear that fell from your eyes, though they were happy tears. “Which is why I have something to ask you.” You continued. You looked to your left where Tom was and saw him down on one knee with a black box in his hands.

With wide eyes, you set the card down and looked at Tom. “The card says it all, love. So, what do you say? Will you marry me?” He asked.

At first, you physically couldn’t form your response so you had to stick with nodding your head rapidly. Tom smiled up at you as he took the ring from the box and slid it on to your finger.

You practically tackled Tom to the floor when you threw your arms around him. “I love you. I love you so much.” You said into the crook of his neck. “And I love you, Y/N. I always will.” Tom said, kissing the top of your head.

February 14th was supposed to be a memorable day for the both of you but February 15th quickly became your favorite day.
